Dashboard Utilities¶

class dashboard.utils.GroupConcat(expression, separator=', ', **extra)¶

Allows Django to use the MySQL GROUP_CONCAT aggregation.

Parameters

separator (str) – the delimiter to use (default=’,’)

Example

Pizza.objects.annotate(
topping_str=GroupConcat(

‘toppings’, separator=’, ‘, distinct=True,

)

)

class dashboard.utils.SimpleTree¶

A simple tree data structure.

This has many methods similar to a dictionary.

>>> pizza = SimpleTree()
>>> pizza["pepperoni"] = 5
>>> pizza["cheese", "no_pickles"] = 3
>>> pizza["cheese", "no_mayo"] = 10
>>> [food for food in t.items()]
       [(('pepperoni',), 5), (('cheese', 'no_pickles'), 3), ...]

Values are returned by default. You can return the SimpleTree object by performing lookups on the “objects” interface. The “parent” attribute will refer to the original parent of the object.

>>> child = t.objects["pizza", "cheese"]
>>> [food for food in child.items()]
       [(('cheese', 'no_pickles'), 5), ...]
>>> [food for food in child.parent.items()]
       [(('pepperoni',), 5), (('cheese', 'no_pickles'), 3), ...]

You can return a dictionary representation with “asdict()”.

>>> pizza.asdict()
        {"name": "root", "children": [{"name": "pepperoni", "value": 5...}]}
objects¶

returns SimpleTrees

Type

SimpleTreeObjectInterface

parent¶

the parent SimpleTree object

Type

SimpleTree

name¶

the node name

Type

str

value¶

the node value

Type

any

children¶

a list of children SimpleTree objects

Type

list

asdict()¶

Return a dictionary representation of the tree.

items() → a set-like object providing a view on D's items¶
keys() → a set-like object providing a view on D's keys¶
values() → an object providing a view on D's values¶
dashboard.utils.clean_dict(odict, model, translations={}, keep_nones=False)¶

Cleans out key:value pairs that aren’t in the model fields

dashboard.utils.get_missing_ids(Model, ids)¶

Evaluate which IDs do not exist in the database

Parameters

  • Model – the model class or queryset to check IDs against

  • ids – a sequence of integers represent the IDs to look up

Optional args:

filter:

Returns

A list of IDs not in the database

dashboard.utils.inheritance_bulk_create(models)¶

A workaround for https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/28821

Parameters

models – a list of models to insert

Note that this handles less edge cases than the official bulk_create. For relatively simple models this will work well though.

dashboard.utils.update_fields(odict, model)¶

Takes a dict and updates the associated fields w/in the model
